instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2337: What is A2337? A2337 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2020 M1 with EMC 3598, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02016..
definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 with no power, that puls 5.16V and 0A from ampmeter.

The mac had liquid contact (water), and UF400/500 CC1/2 and LDO seams to be ok ondiode reading.

I can't find the power aliases on my sdhematics.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi,

Both  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> (measured on F5200) and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> have 0V

<SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> has 0.164 on diode reading and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>  has 0.560 on diode reading

<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_AON_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> also has 0V and 0.510 on diode reading

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is mandatory; is the mother of all other voltages.

Do you get 5V at <RESISTOR>R5220</RESISTOR>?
Post <CHIP>U5200</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDD/P, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi,

Yes, I have 5.171V on  <RESISTOR>R5220</RESISTOR>.

<CHIP>U5200</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> = 5.171V
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 0.006V
VDD = 5.084V
VDDP = 5.082V
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> = 0.001V
AMON = 0.009V
BMON = 0.001V[B][/B]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 0.006V"
Fix this problem; start checking in diode mode.
If bad reading, remove <CAPACITOR>C5216</CAPACITOR> and test again; if still bad, change <CHIP>U5200</CHIP>.
If good reading, replace <RESISTOR>R5215</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 no power
threads.message:
Hi.
Replacing <RESISTOR>R5215</RESISTOR> worked. Thanks.
It always amazes me how you manage to identify the causes. I keep trying to figure out how you figured out that this resistance was the cuplrit, but I can't figure it out. 
Great.
Thanks!
